author: Rm Wolfe

text: Quantic Dream are known to make very story driven games that try to replicate the audiovisual presentation of a movie, but they're sometimes criticized for ignoring the importance of gameplay. It seems to be the case with this game, but I'm still curious to play it someday. The soundtrack is very nice, that's for sure.
author: SupraDarky

text: It's my personal opinion that presentation should never have priority over gameplay. That being said I truly did enjoy this game... Maybe not as a game but as a story or a movie.
author: Rusty

text:
I've been following a silent playthrough that someone has been doing. It's really like watching a movie - and it's very easy to get emotionally attached to the main character, there's a lot of shit going on in that game. Honestly, despite it's quick-time events and all, it really is an impressive game with a decent story to it, if you're one for dramas and all that.
Check it out, it'd be worth the money and time.
author: daaku176
bulbinking

text: @bulbinking I see your point but at the same time the ability to be in control of the "actors" brings you closer to them and makes you so much more invested in the story, and sure this can be outweighed by the fact that this game is nothing but a giant QTE I still found it to be an extremely enjoyable experience, and I honestly think something would be lost if this was to be made into a film or even a book.
author: Rusty

text:
You really don't need to play this one. 
The thing about all of David Cage's 'games' is that they're supposed to be a movie that you can change making choices. That's awesome, and it's a concept that's done so well in Tale Tell games (Like Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us), but the problem is THE CHOICES YOU MAKE HAVE LITTLE TO NO IMPACT ON THE ACTUAL DIRECTION OF THE STORY and the games have been heavily criticized because of that. I can't provide better examples than this game, Fahrenheit and Heavy Rain. David Cage himself said only to play B:TS once. 
It's also been said that if these were in fact movies instead of games, they would flop because the story in all of them is weak once you remove the illusion of choice. 
Please don't support Quantic Dream, support Tell Tale or some other developer with aspirations to make dynamic, player driven narratives.
author: Maakufamous

text:
@bulbinking

author: TheGrowthCycle

text: I used to think I was the last person on Earth to think such a thing, but there is no boundary or borders in place to what makes an experience. I feel sorry for these people who played all the same games as me, watched the same movies as me, and I'm sure thought the same things as me in a different context which all provoked similar feelings. This game warrants a playthrough like anything in life warrants an understanding. I'm sure you could appreciate it for what it has to offer not for what it doesn't.
